docs.lead_paragraph: In their final confrontation before the nation's voters last night, Vice President Al Gore cited accomplishments throughout his public career as evidence that he is a champion of working Americans, while Gov. George W. Bush cast himself as a leader from outside Washington with a record of uniting Republicans and Democrats. The candidates recalibrated their approaches from the first two debates as they prowled a red-carpeted stage at Washington University in St. Louis and fielded questions from ordinary voters. Mr. Gore, who had been criticized even by his own supporters as too brash in the first debate and too restrained in the second, was newly feisty but stopped himself from appearing too combative.

headline.main: Bush and Gore, in Last Debate, Stage Vigorous Give-and-Take

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush take part in final televised presidential debate, town-meeting-style exchange, St Louis; Gore, criticized as too brash in first debate and too restrained in second, is feisty, without seeming too combative; Bush adopts earnest and subdued demeanor; their exchanges are often spirited and intense, with Gore citing his experience in White House and Congress and trying to underscore differences with Bush; Bush seeks to portray Gore as big spender beholden to special interests; event opens with moment of silence for Missouri Gov Mel Carnahan, who died in plane crash; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, supporters of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri had taken to wearing gold lapel pins shaped like straight arrows. The symbolism was clear: Mr. Carnahan's dominant characteristic as a politician was his reputation for being clean and on the level. He was not a scintillating speaker, a back-slapper or a joke-teller, but a politician who pursued his principles in a quiet, confident way, those who knew him said yesterday.

headline.main: Mel Carnahan, 66, Missouri Governor and Democratic Senate Candidate

docs.abstract: Obituary of Mel Carnahan, Missouri governor and Democratic Senate candidate, who died in plane crash at age 66 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although Jon S. Corzine is shattering spending records in his New Jersey race for the United States Senate, most voters either do not know or do not care, a New York Times poll has found. In outspending his Republican opponent, Representative Bob Franks, by about 17 to 1, Mr. Corzine alone has captured the attention of a majority of voters. With three weeks remaining until Election Day, 59 percent of those who responded to the survey said they had no opinion of Mr. Franks. But despite intensive news coverage of Mr. Corzine's campaign finances -- he has poured about $53 million into his Senate bid so far -- he has not encountered widespread resentment from voters over his spending.

headline.main: Poll Finds Corzine Spending Is Not a Problem for Voters

docs.abstract: New York Times poll finds that Jon S Corzine, Democratic candidate for Senate from New Jersey, leads his Republican opponent Repr Robert D Franks 45 percent to 33 percent; finds that Corzine's spending is not a concern to voters; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of labor's effort to help Vice President Al Gore, Minnie Sanchez, a middle-school teacher in San Antonio, came to Michigan today to tell hundreds of union members some unflattering things about life under Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Speaking to 120 union members in this heavily Republican city, Ms. Sanchez sharply attacked Mr. Bush's record, saying Texas ranks 46th in child poverty, 37th in education spending per student and 49th in the percentage of children without health insurance.

headline.main: Members of Texas Unions Attack Governor's Record

docs.abstract: Members of Texas labor unions are campaigning actively for Vice Pres Al Gore; so-called Texas Truth Squad has adddressed labor audiences in 15 cities, attacking policies of Gov George W Bush; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's Child Health Plus program is a model for the nation in providing health insurance for low-income children. About 550,000 children are receiving subsidized coverage under the state program, which was expanded after Congress provided more money through the federal Children's Health Insurance Program that passed in 1997. But New York's admirable record in providing insurance has been marred by administrative problems that now put as many as 130,000 youngsters in danger of being switched out of Child Health Plus because they should have been enrolled in Medicaid instead. Both programs receive federal money, but federal rules require that children eligible for Medicaid be enrolled in that program, and not in Child Health Plus. To correct the situation, the state is now in the process of moving tens of thousands of children from one program to the other.
docs.abstract: Editorial says New York State should make every effort to ensure that no child loses health coverage due to administrative problems that may cause as many as 130,000 youngsters in low-income families to be swtiched out of Child Health Plus subsidized insurance program into Medicaid

docs.lead_paragraph: Three Texas state legislators said today that Gov. George W. Bush had exaggerated state spending on health care for uninsured people in Texas, taking credit for large amounts of charity care provided by private doctors and hospitals. The legislators, all Democrats, made the assertions in separate interviews today and in a letter to Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic candidate for president. The Bush campaign rejected the criticism.

headline.main: Texas Democrats Say Bush Exaggerated State Spending on Health Care for Uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: Beginning the final phase of the presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Bush plans to send the nation's Republican governors in a three-day fly-around to battleground states as well as deploy a phalanx of women and his onetime bitter primary rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona, to woo swing voters. The Bush campaign said 28 of Mr. Bush's fellow Republican governors, including his brother Jeb, of Florida, plan to converge on Austin on Sunday for a rally.

headline.main: Bush Recruits Governors and Women for Final Stretch

docs.lead_paragraph: They lingered in the restricted halls of state government with a familiar air, their cell phones ringing. They huddled with state officials and spent time between appointments lounging outside Governor Pataki's office. They were ubiquitous enough to earn a nickname: the Two Josephs. What annoyed some and amused others was that neither worked for the state; one ran a dress shop, the other a kosher supermarket. The men, Joseph Goldberger and Joseph Menczer, had earned V.I.P. status by helping to raise an estimated $500,000 in 1994 for a little-known gubernatorial candidate named George E. Pataki. Given access upon his election, they peppered state agencies with requests -- always implying that they represented a small Hasidic group in Brooklyn called the Pupa, and often bragging of friends in high places.

headline.main: THE TWO JOSEPHS/A special report.; Uncommon Albany Access Stirs Questions of Improper Influence

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush has written that ''by far the most profound'' decision he or any governor can make is whether to proceed with an execution. ''I get the facts, weigh them thoughtfully and carefully, and decide,'' Mr. Bush wrote in his autobiography. What he did not say is that he normally does this in 15 minutes.

headline.main: A Master of Bipartisanship With No Taste for Details

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton urged Bronx and Harlem churchgoers yesterday to pray for peace in the Middle East, while her opponent, Rick A. Lazio, stumped for votes in western New York, visiting tailgaters assembled for a Buffalo Bills game and Italian-Americans gathered in Geneva for a lasagna dinner in his honor. The contrasting schedules illustrated once again the two campaigns' strategies. Mrs. Clinton has spent four of the last five Sundays at predominantly black churches, working to generate a large turnout among black voters. Mr. Lazio, meanwhile, invested his seventh day in upstate and western New York, seeking to shore up his support in the state's more conservative, and predominantly white, corners.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Visits Harlem as Lazio Courts Upstate Vote
